et: verbal derivative (perhaps with conformation to {et_link|parley:2|parley:2} or French {it}parler{/it} "to speak") of {it}paroli{/it} "series of bets set up so that the original stake and winnings are placed on successive wagers," borrowed from French, borrowed from Italian, plural of {it}parolo{/it} (stress on first syllable), of uncertain origin

Apparently the earliest attestation of the Italian word is in the Italian-English dictionary of John Florio, {it}Queen Anna's New World of Words, or Dictionarie of the Italian and English Tongues{/it} (London, 1611), in which {it}Pároli{/it} is defined as "a grand part set or cast at dice," with a corresponding verb {it}Paroláre{/it} "to set or play at a grand part at dice." French {it}paroli{/it} first appears as a gloss of the Italian word in the Italian-French dictionary of Antoine Oudin, {it}Recherches italiennes et françoises, ou Dictionnaire, contenant outre les mots ordinaires, une quantité de Proverbes & de Phrases{/it} (Paris, 1640), where Italian {it}Paroli{/it} is glossed as "paroli, aux dez" ("paroli, at dice"). C. Battisti and G. Alessio ({it}Dizionario etimologico italiano,{/it} Florence, 1954) characterize {it}parolo{/it} as Neapolitan ("voce napoletano") and adduce additionally Sicilian {it}pàrula{/it} "doppia posta nel giuoco del faraone o bassetta" ("double stake in the game of faro or basset [a game similar to faro]"), which they aver to be a derivative of {it}paro{/it} "equal." Opposing these conjectures is the entry {it}párolo{/it} in a list of dialect words from Lucca in Tuscany, along with their etymologies, compiled by Silvio Pieri ("Appunti etimologici," {it}Zeitschrift für romanische Philologie,{/it} Band 30 [1903], p. 302). Pieri proposes that the word is a univerbation of {it}paro lo{/it} "I offer it (hold it out)," referring to the sum wagered. This etymology is seconded by the {it}Oxford English Dictionary,{/it} third edition, and the {it}Trésor de la langue française.{/it}
shortdef: to increase or otherwise transform into something of much greater value

dt: {bc}a series of two or more bets so set up in advance that the original stake plus its winnings are risked on the successive wagers
{bc}the fresh risking of an original stake together with its winnings
